description: These scenarios have different victory conditions, special rules, or both. Warband-Building Scenarios: In these scenarios, one player or all players alter their warbands in some way.
name: Basic Scenarios

description: First, the players decide how many points each warband should have (the default is 100 points), then all players design their war- bands. Next, the players choose a scenario and set up the battle. Instead of choosing a scenario, you can roll ran- domly to determine which one you play. Rarely, a formed unit has melee contact with an enemy unit only on a corner. In this case, the contact is considered to be along whichever edge is closer to the enemy unit. For example, a ranged unit can stand just inside the edge of a woods and shoot out at enemies without penalty while benefiting from cover itself.

description: Woods are the only stan- dard terrain type that provides partial cover. Low Cover Low cover works like partial cover, except that the defender has to be near the terrain for it to provide any protection.
name: Partial Cover Terrain Types

description: Low cover applies only to units within 6 inches of the terrain.
name: Cover Range

description: An attacking unit can ignore terrain that provides low cover if it is closer to that terrain than the defending unit is. That is, any low cover that’s closer to the attacking unit than the defending unit doesn’t provide cover for the defender.

description: A unit with this special ability can move, make a mass strike, then move again, as long as the distance it moves during its turn doesn’t exceed its speed. If it moves away from a unit that engages it, it provokes an attack of opportunity nor- mally and must end at least 1 inch away from that unit, but it does not need to make a morale save.
name: Spring Attack

name: Partial Cover

description: It costs 2 squares to move into a square containing difficult terrain (3 squares if moving diagonally).
name: Difficult Terrain

description: A character with levels in the archmage pres- tige class (see the Dungeon Master’s Guide,  page 179), though highly accomplished mages are often referred to as archmages even if they don ’t have actual archmage levels.
name: Archmage

description: A member of the warlock class, described in this book beginning on page 5.
name: Warlock

description: Many warlocks are champions of dark and chaotic powers. Long ago, they (or in some cases, their ancestors) forged grim pacts with dangerous extraplanar powers, trading portions of their souls in exchange for supernatural power. While many warlocks have turned away from evil, seeking to undo the wrongs of their former colleagues, they are still chained by the old pacts through which they acquired their powers. The demand to further the designs of their dark patrons, o r  t o  r e s ist  th e m ,  dri v e s  m ost  w ar l ocks  t o  se e k  th e opportunities for power, wealth, and great deeds (for good or ill) offered by adventuring.
name: Adventures

description: Warlocks are often chaotic or evil (and more than a few are both). The powers they serve can be cruel, capricious, and wild, unbound by con- ventional views of right and wrong. However, even warlocks who derive their powers from the most sinister of patrons have been known to turn the black powers at their command against evil. A good-aligned warlock is a grim and fear- some enemy of evil. All too familiar with the darkness lurking in his heart, he gazes un ﬂ inch- ingly on the evil in others and battles the foulest of foes without fear.
name: CLASSESAlignment

description: Warlocks know ﬁ rsthand the power of supernatural beings, so they do not scorn religion. Evil warlocks sometimes seek the favor of cruel and bloodthirsty deities, while good warlocks often turn to the worship of noble and true deities for the strength to win the battle raging in their tortured souls.
name: Religion

description: Ambitious and often un- principled, humans are the most likely to seek out the danger- ous shortcuts to power that l e a d  t o  lif e  as  w ar l ocks. Half-orcs are common as warlocks as well, since they often ﬁ nd that the powers that create warlocks do not discriminate against individ- uals of mixed heritage. Warlocks of other races are rare at best. Other
name: Races

description: A high Charisma score makes a warlock ’s invocations harder to resist. High Dexterity is very valuable to a warlock, allowing him to better aim his eldritch blasts, and a good Constitution score is also useful. Alignment:  Any evil or any chaotic.
name: Abilities

description: Target must make Will save or become shaken. Sickening Blast:  T a r g e t  m u s t  m a k e  F o r t i t u d e  s a v e  o r become sickened. Lesser Eldritch Essence Invocations
name: Frightful Blast

description: Target must make Fortitude save or become blind for 1 round.
name: Beshadowed Blast

description: Blast deals ﬁ re damage and target must make Re ﬂ ex save or catch ﬁ re.
name: Brimstone Blast

description: Blast deals cold damage and target must make Fortitude save or take –2 penalty to Dexterity. Greater Eldritch Essence Invocations
name: Hellrime Blast

description: T a r g e t  m u s t  m a k e  W i l l  s a v e  o r  b e confused for 1 round.
name: Bewitching Blast

description: Blast range increases to 250 feet.
name: Eldritch Spear

description: Melee attack channels eldritch blast. Lesser Blast Shape Invocation
name: Hideous Blow

description: Blast jumps from initial target to second- ary targets. Greater Blast Shape Invocation
name: Eldritch Chain

description: Blast takes the shape of a cone. Dark Blast Shape Invocation
name: Eldritch Cone

description: De ﬂ ect incoming ranged attacks, leave no trail, and prevent being tracked by scent. Leaps and Bounds:  Gain bonus on Balance, Jump, and Tumble checks.
name: Entropic Warding

description: Create a cloud of mist that grants conceal- ment and fatigues those who enter. 620_17925_Chpt1.indd   9 620_17925_Chpt1.indd   9 9/15/04   9:20:52 AM 9/15/04   9:20:52 AM10 CHAPTER 1

name: Voidsense

name: Dark Discorporation

description: Baleful utterance.
name: Invocations Known

description: Toughness.
name: Feat

description: Point Blank Shot.
name: Bonus Feat

description: Warmages ﬁ nd they have little in common with sorcerers and wizards, who learn their craft without the rigors or discipline of a warmage ’s apprenticeship. In fact, warmages are likely to be more comfortable with the regimented classes —those that appreciate military train- ing—such as paladins, monks, and ﬁ ghters.
name: Other Classes

description: Toughness.
name: Bonus Feat

description: Once per day, a wu jen can reroll an initiative roll she has just made before she knows her place in the initiative order. She takes the better of the two rolls.
name: Watchful Spirit

description: Any nongood.
name: Alignment

description: M ust h a v e m a d e pea ce ful co n ta ct wi th a sum - moned evil outsider.

description: The inclusion of the alienist in your campaign world, as printed here, requires that you make some basic assumptions about the cosmology of your campaign: Places far worse than Hell exist in the multiverse, and even demons have more in common with characters than the entities that exist outside what is known, a mere glimpse of which can drive the sanity from someone ’s mind. If you prefer that demons and devils retain their top seat in the hierarchy of evil, you can adjust this prestige class so that the alienist has congress with demons instead of the nebulous entities of the Far Realm. Hit Die:  d4. Requirements To qualify to become an alienist, a character must ful ﬁ ll all the following criteria. Alignment:  Any nonlawful.
name: Adaptation

description: Knowledge (the planes) 8 ranks.
name: Skills

description: Augment Summoning.
name: Feat

description: Beginning at 5th level, an alienist ’s familiar, if any, gains the pseudonatural template (see page 160) in addition to the powers and abilities normal for a familiar of the appropriate level. This effect does not replace an existing familiar —the familiar has been slowly taking on pseudonatural aspects as the alienist rises in level, and those characteristics become fully functional at this point. From now on, the alienist ’s newly summoned familiars already possess the pseudonatural template. If an alienist has no familiar, this ability has no effect.
name: Pseudonatural Familiar

description: Adapting this class to other methods of play might include the idea of draining luck from NPCs, and using that drained luck as stored spin. However, determining the method whereby this luck is drained that doesn ’t merely allow the fatespinner to always have a method of rejuvenating his spin is tricky . This effect could potentially be tied to the ﬁ ckle ﬁ nger of fate ability; if the fatespinner successfully uses this ability, he gains 1 additional point of spin that he must use within 1 round (he can ’t store it). This ability should be usable only once per day. Hit Die: d4. Requirements To qualify to become a fatespinner, a character must ful ﬁ ll all the following criteria.
name: Adaptation

description: Knowledge (arcana) 10 ranks, Profession (gambler) 5 ranks.
name: Skills

description: It would be easy to postulate that the base material from which the prestige class derives its name is some other substance, even without changing the abilities derived from the material in any way. Thus, a practitioner of this prestige class could instead take his powers from quartz, jade, sapphire, iron, black iron, steel, or some other substance known for (among other things) solidity. Hit Die:  d8. Requirements To qualify to become a Green Star adept, a character must fulﬁ ll all the following criteria.
name: Adaptation

description: One way to adapt this prestige class is to alter the premise of the initiate ’s focus on color. Instead of color, an initiate might be attempting to understand a philosophi-cal hierarchy, a text of seven fables, seven words of power, or something else entirely. Hit Die:  d4. Requirements To qualify to become an Initiate of the Sevenfold Veil, a character must ful ﬁ ll all the following criteria.
name: Adaptation

description: Female half-elf bard 10/seeker of the song 2; CR 12; Medium humanoid (elf ); HD 12d6+12; hp 56; Init +5; Spd 30 ft.; AC 19, touch 13, ﬂ at-footed 18; Base Atk +8; Grp +7; Atk +8 melee (1d6/18 –20, + 1 cold iron rapier ) or +9 ranged touch (wand); Full Atk +8/+3 melee (1d6/18 –20, + 1 cold iron rapier ) or +9 ranged touch (wand); SA seeker music (burning melody, song of unmaking); SQ bardic knowledge 10, bardic music 12/day (countersong, fascinate,  inspire com- petence, inspire courage +2, inspire greatness, suggestion ), combine songs, half-elf traits, low-light vision, rapture of the song; AL N; SV Fort +6, Ref +8, Will +12; Str 8, Dex 13, Con 12, Int 10, Wis 14, Cha 20.
name: Maralea Duskwood

description: Maralea can spend a daily use of bardic music to activate a special seeker music effect. While the effect is active, she can spend another daily use to activate the song ’s refrain, if any, as a swift action. Burning Melody (Su):  While Maralea sings this song, she and all of her allies within 30 feet who can hear her gain resistance to ﬁ re 15. An ally bene ﬁ ts from this effect for as long as it can hear Maralea sing.
name: Seeker Music

description: The notion of an elite order of warrior-mages is not restricted to the Greyhawk setting. You can easily adapt the arcanamach to your own campaign, even if you do not play in Greyhawk. In the F ORGOTTEN  REALMS setting, the arcanamach can be a student of the elite warrior traditions of the Empire of Netheril, the Imaskari Empire, or even the realms of Jhaamdath or Mulhorand. Simply change the language requirement to an appropriate dead language for the empire in question (Loross, Roushoum, Thorass, or Mulhorandi), and the class should work well with no further modi ﬁ cation.
name: Adaptation
